title: Pre-sequester jobs numbers, unemployment rate better than expected
content:
The economy added 236,000 jobs in February and unemployment dropped to 7.7 percent . Job numbers up big before sequester
New jobs numbers released Friday revealed a February spike in hiring , as the economy showed better-than-expected job growth in the final weeks before a round of federal spending cuts went into effect that economists warn could wipe the gains away .
Democrats have called for delaying the cuts while Republicans have pushed to limit their impact on the military , but so far there has been little evidence the two parties are ready to strike any deals .
The positive news failed to budge either camp from its corner , and both Republicans and the White House pivoted off the news to push their own solutions to the longstanding budget battle .
“ Any job creation is positive news , but the fact is unemployment in America is still way above the levels the Obama White House projected when the trillion-dollar stimulus spending bill was enacted , and the federal government ’ s ongoing spending binge has resulted in a debt that exceeds the size of our entire economy , ” Speaker John Boehner said in a statement .
The White House warned of the need to blunt the sequester ’ s impact – and put the onus on Congress to get a deal done .
“ The Administration continues to urge Congress to move toward a sustainable Federal budget in a responsible way that balances tax loophole closing , entitlement reform , and sensible spending cuts , while making critical investments in the economy that promote growth and job creation and protecting our most vulnerable citizens , ” Alan Krueger , chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers , said in a statement .
The economy added 236,000 jobs in February while unemployment dropped to 7.7 percent from 7.9 percent , federal economists reported Friday . The number far surpassed analyst predictions that 165,000 jobs would be added in February .
The jobs report is the last before the economy begins to feel the after-effects of the sequester , a set of across-the-board federal spending cuts that went into effect this month . The Congressional Budget Office says the sequester will cost 750,000 jobs in 2013 and shave 0.6 percent off of economic growth .
The report is a bright spot amid some signs of potential trouble for the economy . Economic growth was almost completely stagnant in the last quarter of 2012 , and overall the economy remains stuck on a track of slow growth that has failed to undo the damage of the 2008-09 recession .
February saw a significant bump in construction jobs , as the sector added 48,000 new workers . And 17,000 of those jobs were in new home construction , another in a string of signs that the long-stagnant housing sector — which has been instrumental to past post-recession recoveries — is beginning to recover .
The monthly jobs number is a snapshot and economists warn that the long-term trend is far more important than one month .
Among the few blemishes on Friday ’ s report was a downward revision to the January job count . After collecting more data , the federal economists now say 119,000 jobs were added in January , down from their initial estimate of 157,000 jobs .
content_original:
The economy added 236,000 jobs in February and unemployment dropped to 7.7 percent. Job numbers up big before sequester

New jobs numbers released Friday revealed a February spike in hiring, as the economy showed better-than-expected job growth in the final weeks before a round of federal spending cuts went into effect that economists warn could wipe the gains away.

Democrats have called for delaying the cuts while Republicans have pushed to limit their impact on the military, but so far there has been little evidence the two parties are ready to strike any deals.

Story Continued Below

The positive news failed to budge either camp from its corner, and both Republicans and the White House pivoted off the news to push their own solutions to the longstanding budget battle.

( The Scrum Podcast: Analysis on Obama’s GOP outreach, Rand Paul’s filibuster)

“Any job creation is positive news, but the fact is unemployment in America is still way above the levels the Obama White House projected when the trillion-dollar stimulus spending bill was enacted, and the federal government’s ongoing spending binge has resulted in a debt that exceeds the size of our entire economy,” Speaker John Boehner said in a statement.

The White House warned of the need to blunt the sequester’s impact – and put the onus on Congress to get a deal done.

“The Administration continues to urge Congress to move toward a sustainable Federal budget in a responsible way that balances tax loophole closing, entitlement reform, and sensible spending cuts, while making critical investments in the economy that promote growth and job creation and protecting our most vulnerable citizens,” Alan Krueger, chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers, said in a statement.

The economy added 236,000 jobs in February while unemployment dropped to 7.7 percent from 7.9 percent, federal economists reported Friday. The number far surpassed analyst predictions that 165,000 jobs would be added in February.

The jobs report is the last before the economy begins to feel the after-effects of the sequester, a set of across-the-board federal spending cuts that went into effect this month. The Congressional Budget Office says the sequester will cost 750,000 jobs in 2013 and shave 0.6 percent off of economic growth.

The report is a bright spot amid some signs of potential trouble for the economy. Economic growth was almost completely stagnant in the last quarter of 2012, and overall the economy remains stuck on a track of slow growth that has failed to undo the damage of the 2008-09 recession.

February saw a significant bump in construction jobs, as the sector added 48,000 new workers. And 17,000 of those jobs were in new home construction, another in a string of signs that the long-stagnant housing sector — which has been instrumental to past post-recession recoveries — is beginning to recover.

The monthly jobs number is a snapshot and economists warn that the long-term trend is far more important than one month.

Among the few blemishes on Friday’s report was a downward revision to the January job count. After collecting more data, the federal economists now say 119,000 jobs were added in January, down from their initial estimate of 157,000 jobs.
